## 2. Background

### 2.1. Asthma and Respiratory Distress

Asthma is a chronic inflammatory disease of the airways that causes recurrent episodes of wheezing, breathlessness, chest tightness, and coughing. Asthma affects 8.3% of children in the United States (Akinbami et al., 2012), with prevalence increasing in recent decades. Asthma is the third most common chronic disease among children and the leading cause of school absenteeism due to chronic illness (CDC, 2018). In 2015, asthma accounted for 1.7 million emergency department (ED) visits, 439,000 hospitalizations, and 3,328 deaths among children and adults (Akinbami et al., 2018). Asthma is also a leading cause of pediatric hospitalizations in the United States, with 1.7 million hospitalizations in 2014 (Akinbami et al., 2018). Asthma is more common among non-Hispanic black children than among non-Hispanic white children (Akinbami et al., 2012). Asthma disproportionately affects low-income and minority children, with higher rates of asthma-related ED visits and hospitalizations among black and Hispanic children (Akinbami et al., 2018). Asthma is also associated with higher rates of school absenteeism and lower rates of academic achievement (Akinbami et al., 2012).

### 2.2. Asthma Management

Asthma management involves a combination of pharmacological and non-pharmacological interventions to control symptoms and prevent exacerbations. Pharmacological interventions include the use of inhaled corticosteroids, long-acting beta-agonists, and leukotriene modifiers to control inflammation and reduce the risk of exacerbations. Non-pharmacological interventions include environmental controls, such as avoiding triggers such as allergens, irritants, and pollutants, and lifestyle modifications, such as regular exercise and a healthy diet. Asthma management also involves the use of rescue medications, such as short-acting beta-agonists, to relieve symptoms during exacerbations. Asthma management is a complex process that requires ongoing monitoring and adjustment of treatment regimens to achieve optimal control of symptoms and prevent exacerbations.

### 2.3. Asthma Exacerbations

Asthma exacerbations are episodes of worsening asthma symptoms that require immediate medical attention. Exacerbations can be triggered by a variety of factors, including exposure to allergens, irritants, and pollutants, as well as viral infections. Symptoms of an asthma exacerbation include wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, and coughing. Exacerbations can range from mild to severe, with severe exacerbations requiring emergency medical attention. Asthma exacerbations can be life-threatening and can lead to hospitalization or even death if not treated promptly and appropriately. Early detection and treatment of asthma exacerbations are critical to preventing serious complications and improving outcomes.

### 2.4. Asthma Safety Programs

Asthma safety programs are designed to prevent asthma exacerbations and improve outcomes for patients with asthma. These programs typically involve the use of telehealth technologies, such as remote monitoring devices and mobile apps, to monitor patients’ respiratory status and detect early signs of exacerbations. Asthma safety programs can also include educational interventions to help patients and their caregivers better manage their asthma and prevent exacerbations. The goal of asthma safety programs is to improve asthma control and reduce the risk of exacerbations, leading to better health outcomes and reduced healthcare costs.
